title: Getting started - working in the cloud

# Getting started: Working with DocStatic in the Cloud
Welcome! This guide walks you through setting up DocStatic for the first time.
If you’ve never worked with GitHub or docs-as-code before, don’t worry — we’ll explain what’s needed, why, and where to find more detail.
## Prerequisites
You can run DocStatic locally (on your computer) or host it in the cloud. In this article, we explain how to host it in the cloud.
For the easiest cloud setup, create free accounts with these services:
* [GitHub](https://github.com/) — stores your content and tracks changes
* [TinaCMS](https://tina.io/) — enables browser-based editing
* [LanguageTool](https://languagetool.org/) — provides optional grammar and style checking
***
## Fork the DocStatic repository
DocStatic’s source code lives on GitHub. To start, you’ll need to fork it. This gives you a personal copy that you can use in your own repository, without affecting the original version.
1. Log in to your account in GitHub.
2. Visit [https://github.com/aowendev/docstatic](https://github.com/aowendev/docstatic).
3. Click **Fork** (it is usually to the top-right).
4. Leave the default **Repository name** in place.
5. Enter a description of your project.
6. Make sure **Copy the main branch only** is checked.
7. Click **Create fork**.
***
## Project structure
After forking and cloning the repository, you will see various files in your in your `docstatic/` folder. Below, we've included **some** of the project structure files and folders that you need to be aware of. **It is not a complete list of everything in the project**.
```
docstatic
├── apis
│ └── petstore.yaml
├── blog
│ └── hybrid.mdx
├── config
│ ├── docusaurus
│ │ └── index.json
│ ├── homepage
│ │ └── index.json
│ └── sidebar
│ └── index.json
│
├── docs
│ └── introduction.mdx
├── i18n
│ └── fr
├── reuse
│ ├── code
│ │ └── example.xml
│ ├── conditions
│ │ └── index.json
│ ├── glossaryTerms
│ │ └── index.json
│ ├── snippets
│ │ └── example.mdx
│ ├── taxonomy
│ │ └── index.json
│ ├── variableSets
│ │ └── index.json
│ ├── code-files.json
│ └── snippets-files.json
├── src
│ ├── css
│ │ └── custom.css
│ └── pages
│ ├── example-page.mdx
│ ├── index.js
│ └── index.module.css
├── static
│ └── img
├── docusaurus.config.ts
├── package.json
├── README.md
├── sidebars.ts
└── yarn.lock
```
### Project structure rundown
* `/apis/` - OpenAPI YAML files.
* `/blog/` - Blog MDX files.
* `/config/` - JSON files used by TinaCMS to configure DocStatic.
* `/docs/` - Docs MDX files.
* `/i18n/` - Translation files.
* `/reuse/` - Reusable content.
* `/src/` - Non-documentation files like pages or custom React components.
* `/src/pages` - Any JSX/TSX/MDX file within this directory are converted into a website page.
* `/static/` - Static folder. Any content inside here is copied into the root of the final build folder.
* `/docusaurus.config.ts` - A config file containing the site configuration.
* `/package.json` - A DocStatic website is a React app. You can install and use any npm packages you want.
* `/sidebars.ts` - Specifies the order of documents in the sidebar. Use this for your “table of contents” structure.
Next, let's look at where you'll need to create and store your documentation files.
***
## Clear the Docs folder
The Docs folder contains a copy of the DocStatic documentation. The idea is that you clear out the DocStatic documentation. When you create your own documentation, you should save it to the Docs folder.
***
## Monorepos
DocStatic allows the use of a single repo that contains both the project code and the project documentation. In Docusaurus terminology, this concept is called a “monorepo”.
For more information, see [Monorepos](https://docusaurus.io/docs/installation#monorepos) in the Docusaurus documentation.
***
## Preview changes
To preview your changes as you edit the files, you can run a **local development server** that will serve your website and reflect the latest changes.
Open a terminal or command prompt and enter:
```shell
yarn dev
```
By default, a browser window will open at [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000).
***
## Build
DocStatic uses a static site generator to build the website into a folder of static contents and put it on a web server where it can be viewed. To build the website, use:
```shell
yarn build-local
```
The contents are generated in the `/build` folder, which you can copy to any static file hosting service such as GitHub pages, Netlify or Vercel. For more information, refer to [Deployment](https://docusaurus.io/docs/deployment) in the Docusaurus documentation.

title: Getting started - working locally
description: >-
Learn how to set up DocStatic so that you can work locally on your computer
instead of in the Cloud.
draft: true
review: false
translate: false
approved: false

# Getting started for working with DocStatic locally
Welcome! This guide walks you through setting up DocStatic for the first time.
If you’ve never worked with GitHub or docs-as-code before, don’t worry — we’ll explain what’s needed, why, and where to find more detail.
## Prerequisites
You can run DocStatic locally (on your computer) or host it in the cloud. Here, we explain how to set it up to work locally.
Before you begin, you'll need:
* [GitHub ](https://github.com/)— create a free account. GitHub will store your content and track changes.
* An Integrated Development Environment (IDE) or a text editor. Two open-source options are:
* [Eclipse](https://eclipseide.org)
* [VSCodium](https://vscodium.com/)
When you have those in place, you can begin the installation (as described in this article).
***
## Install Node.js
You need to install [Node.js](https://nodejs.org/) version 18.0 or above as DocStatic uses its build tools.
First, check if you have Node.js installed already:
1. Open a terminal (Command Prompt or Terminal app).
2. Run:
```
node -v
```
If you see a version number starting with **v18 or higher**, you already have a suitable version of Node.js installed.
If Node.js is **not installed** or you have an **older version**:
1. Go to the [official Node.js downloads](https://nodejs.org/en/download/prebuilt-installer) page.
2. Choose the LTS (Long-Term Support) version for your operating system.
The installer includes npm, the Node Package Manager, which you'll need in later steps.
3. During installation:
* Keep the default options selected (these include required dependencies)
* When the installer finishes, close and reopen your terminal.
4. (Optional) if you work on different projects that need different Node versions, install nvm ([Node Version Manager](https://github.com/nvm-sh/nvm)). With nvm, you can switch between versions of Node without breaking your setup.
Next: Install Yarn.
***
## Install Yarn
DocStatic uses Yarn for package management.
Check if Yarn is already installed.
1. Open your terminal or command prompt.
2. Type:
```
yarn -v
```
If you see a version number, Yarn is already installed.
If you get a “command not found” message or similar error:
1. Open a terminal (Command Prompt or Terminal app)
2. Run:
```
npm install -g yarn
```
<Admonition type="note" title="Note">
On macOS or Linux, you might need to prefix the command with sudo to grant permission:
```
sudo npm install -g yarn
```
</Admonition>
<Admonition type="note" title="Note">
On Windows, you don’t use sudo. Just open your terminal as Administrator and run the command.
</Admonition>
Next: Fork the DocStatic repository
***
## Fork the DocStatic repository
DocStatic’s source code lives on GitHub. To start, you’ll need to fork the repository.
When you fork a repository, you create your own personal copy of it in GitHub. As it is your own copy, you have management rights for it and can to push content into it. This is how you work on a repository without affecting the original DocStatic repository.
1. Log in to your account in GitHub.
2. Visit [https://github.com/aowendev/docstatic](https://github.com/aowendev/docstatic).
3. Click **Fork** (it is usually to the top-right).
4. Leave the default **Repository name** in place.
5. Enter a description of your project.
6. Make sure **Copy the main branch only** is checked.
7. Click **Create fork**.
GitHub makes a new branch of the repository in your GitHub account.
Next: Clone your fork.
***
## Clone your fork of the DocStatic repository
Cloning allows you to work locally on content that you will push to your fork on GitHub.
* Fork = ownership on GitHub
* Clone = ability to work locally
To create a clone:
1. Log in to your GitHub account.
2. Navigate to the repository for the fork.
3. Click on the repository to open it.
4. Click on **\<> Code** and then copy the url.
5. Open your terminal or command prompt.
6. Use `cd` to navigate to the location where you want to store the clone. For example, `cd Documents/Projects/`.
7. Enter `git clone` followed by the url of your clone.
```shell
git clone https://github.com/acme-projects/docstatic.git
```
Next: Install the project dependencies.
***
## Install the project dependencies
To work locally, you also need to install the project dependencies.
1. Open your terminal or command prompt.
2. Use `cd` to navigate to the root folder of your cloned or forked DocStatic repository and install the packages:
```
cd docstatic
yarn install
```
Yarn will download everything listed in package.json. This may take a few minutes.
You've now set everything up. Next, let's look at the project structure.
***
## Project structure
After forking and cloning the repository, you will see various files in your in your `docstatic/` folder. Below, we've included **some** of the project structure files and folders that you need to be aware of. **It is not a complete list of everything in the project**.
```
docstatic
├── apis
│ └── petstore.yaml
├── blog
│ └── hybrid.mdx
├── config
│ ├── docusaurus
│ │ └── index.json
│ ├── homepage
│ │ └── index.json
│ └── sidebar
│ └── index.json
│
├── docs
│ └── introduction.mdx
├── i18n
│ └── fr
├── reuse
│ ├── code
│ │ └── example.xml
│ ├── conditions
│ │ └── index.json
│ ├── glossaryTerms
│ │ └── index.json
│ ├── snippets
│ │ └── example.mdx
│ ├── taxonomy
│ │ └── index.json
│ ├── variableSets
│ │ └── index.json
│ ├── code-files.json
│ └── snippets-files.json
├── src
│ ├── css
│ │ └── custom.css
│ └── pages
│ ├── example-page.mdx
│ ├── index.js
│ └── index.module.css
├── static
│ └── img
├── docusaurus.config.ts
├── package.json
├── README.md
├── sidebars.ts
└── yarn.lock
```
### Project structure rundown
* `/apis/` - OpenAPI YAML files.
* `/blog/` - Blog MDX files.
* `/config/` - JSON files used by TinaCMS to configure DocStatic.
* `/docs/` - Docs MDX files.
* `/i18n/` - Translation files.
* `/reuse/` - Reusable content.
* `/src/` - Non-documentation files like pages or custom React components.
* `/src/pages` - Any JSX/TSX/MDX file within this directory are converted into a website page.
* `/static/` - Static folder. Any content inside here is copied into the root of the final build folder.
* `/docusaurus.config.ts` - A config file containing the site configuration.
* `/package.json` - A DocStatic website is a React app. You can install and use any npm packages you want.
* `/sidebars.ts` - Specifies the order of documents in the sidebar. Use this for your “table of contents” structure.
Next, let's look at where you'll need to create and store your documentation files.
***
## Clear the Docs folder
The Docs folder contains a copy of the DocStatic documentation. The idea is that you clear out the DocStatic documentation. When you create your own documentation, you should save it to the Docs folder.
***
## Monorepos
DocStatic allows the use of a single repo that contains both the project code and the project documentation. In Docusaurus terminology, this concept is called a “monorepo”.
For more information, see [Monorepos](https://docusaurus.io/docs/installation#monorepos) in the Docusaurus documentation.
***
## Preview changes
To preview your changes as you edit the files, you can run a **local development server** that will serve your website and reflect the latest changes.
Open a terminal or command prompt and enter:
```shell
yarn dev
```
By default, a browser window will open at [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000).
***
## Build
DocStatic uses a static site generator to build the website into a folder of static contents and put it on a web server where it can be viewed. To build the website, use:
```shell
yarn build-local
```
The contents are generated in the `/build` folder, which you can copy to any static file hosting service such as GitHub pages, Netlify or Vercel. For more information, refer to [Deployment](https://docusaurus.io/docs/deployment) in the Docusaurus documentation.

yarn build-local

The contents are generated in the `/build` folder, which you can copy to any static file hosting service such as GitHub pages, Netlify or Vercel. For more information, refer to [Deployment](https://docusaurus.io/docs/deployment) in the Docusaurus documentation.

notes.note: title:Adding the CMS to an iPad home screen

segment.source:
---
title: Adding the CMS to an iPad home screen
description: Adding the CMS to an iPad home screen
tags:
- "content-management-systems"
- "content-management-systems_tinacms"
- "software"
- "software_browsers"
- "software_browsers_safari"
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
lastmod: "2026-01-10T08:50:22.852Z"
---
With Apple iPadOS you can convert any web page into a web app that runs in its own instance of Safari with its own icon on your home screen. You can use this ability to create an app for the cloud hosted CMS.
1. Sign in to the CMS.
2. Navigate to the collection you want to use as the home page. For example, the **Topics** collection or the **Table of Contents**.
3. Tap the **Share** icon, tap **More** ( **…** ) and tap **Add to Home Screen** ( **+** ).
4. Give the app a name. By default it will use TinaCMS.
5. Click **Add**.
segment.target:
---
title: Ajouter le CMS à l'écran d'accueil d'un iPad
description: Ajouter le CMS à l'écran d'accueil d'un iPad
tags:
- "content-management-systems"
- "content-management-systems_tinacms"
- "software"
- "software_browsers"
- "software_browsers_safari"
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
lastmod: "2025-10-27T10:25:03.575Z"
---
Avec l'iPadOS d'Apple, vous pouvez convertir n'importe quelle page web en une application web qui s'exécute dans sa propre instance de Safari avec sa propre icône sur votre écran d'accueil. Vous pouvez utiliser cette capacité pour créer une application pour le CMS hébergé dans le nuage.
1. Connectez-vous au CMS.
2. Naviguez jusqu'à la collection que vous souhaitez utiliser comme page d'accueil. Par exemple, la collection **Topics** ou la **Table of Contents**.
3. Appuyez sur l'icône **Partager**, appuyez sur **Plus** ( **…** ) et appuyez sur **Ajouter à l'écran d'accueil** ( **+** ).
4. Donnez un nom à l'application. Par défaut, elle utilisera TinaCMS.
5. Cliquez sur **Ajouter**.

segment.source:
---
title: Front Matter CMS
lastmod: "2025-10-19T14:25:03.377Z"
description: Using the Front Matter CMS plugin in VSCodium.
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
When creating content in an IDE such as [VSCodium](https://vscodium.com/), features provided by the CMS are not available. A typical workflow has developers create or edit content by directly modifying the MDX file in the IDE with writers cleaning up and tagging the content in the CMS. If the developer forgets to include a last modified date, then you have to look at the file properties to get that information. However, there is a lightweight CMS available as a plugin called [Front Matter](https://frontmatter.codes/). The DocStatic repository includes an example Front Matter configuration. For more information, refer to the Front Matter [documentation](https://frontmatter.codes/docs).
segment.target:
---
title: Front Matter CMS
lastmod: "2025-10-19T14:25:14.714Z"
description: Utilisation du plugin Front Matter CMS dans VSCodium.
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
Lors de la création de contenu dans un IDE tel que [VSCodium](https://vscodium.com/), les fonctionnalités fournies par le CMS ne sont pas disponibles. Dans un flux de travail typique, les développeurs créent ou modifient le contenu en modifiant directement le fichier MDX dans l'IDE, tandis que les rédacteurs nettoient et étiquettent le contenu dans le CMS. Si le développeur oublie d'inclure une date de dernière modification, il faut alors consulter les propriétés du fichier pour obtenir cette information. Il existe toutefois un CMS léger disponible sous la forme d'un plugin appelé [Front Matter](https://frontmatter.codes/). Le référentiel DocStatic contient un exemple de configuration de Front Matter. Pour plus d'informations, consultez la [documentation](https://frontmatter.codes/docs) Front Matter.

segment.source:
---
title: Hosted CMS
description: Using DocStatic with cloud-hosted or self-hosted TinaCMS.
tags:
- "software"
- "software_content-management-systems"
- "software_content-management-systems_tinacms"
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
lastmod: "2026-01-25T00:21:23.909Z"
---
# Hosted CMS
One of the two core components of DocStatic is the CMS (the other is the SSG). Until now, you have most likely used only the local version, invoked from the command line with `yarn dev`. But DocStatic also supports two ways of using a hosted version of the CMS.
## TinaCloud
The easiest hosted CMS option is [TinaCloud](https://tina.io/docs/tinacloud). You can [register](https://app.tina.io/register) for a free account, connect it to your GitHub repository and start using it immediately. The free tier suports up to two users, which may be sufficient for lone writers and small docs teams. If you need more users, Tina offers a variety of [pricing plans](https://tina.io/pricing) for different budgets.
## Self hosted
Because TinaCMS is open-source, you have the option of [self-hosting](https://tina.io/docs/self-hosted/overview). In this case there are no subscription fees, but you will need a development team to set up your Tina instance and you'll have to provide your own support.
segment.target:
---
title: CMS hébergé
lastmod: '2025-10-19T12:39:31.732Z'
description: Utiliser DocStatic avec TinaCMS hébergé dans le nuage ou auto-hébergé.
tags:
- software
- software_content-management-systems
- software_content-management-systems_tinacms
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
# CMS hébergé
L'un des deux composants principaux de DocStatic est le CMS (l'autre étant le SSG). Jusqu'à présent, vous n'avez probablement utilisé que la version locale, invoquée à partir de la ligne de commande avec `yarn dev`. Mais, DocStatic supporte également deux façons d'utiliser une version hébergée du CMS.
## TinaCloud
L'option de CMS hébergé la plus simple est [TinaCloud](https://tina.io/docs/tinacloud). Vous pouvez [vous inscrire](https://app.tina.io/register) pour un compte gratuit, le connecter à votre dépôt GitHub et commencer à l'utiliser immédiatement. La version gratuite prend en charge jusqu'à deux utilisateurs, ce qui peut être suffisant pour les rédacteurs isolés et les petites équipes de documentation. Si vous avez besoin de plus d'utilisateurs, Tina propose une variété de [plans tarifaires](https://tina.io/pricing) pour différents budgets.
## Auto-hébergé
TinaCMS étant un logiciel libre, vous pouvez de l'[auto-héberger](https://tina.io/docs/self-hosted/overview). Dans ce cas, aucuns frais n'existent d'abonnement. Vous aurez besoin d'une équipe de développement pour mettre en place votre instance de Tina et vous devrez fournir votre propre support.

segment.source:
---
title: Notifications
description: Sending workflow notifications to email, Slack or Teams.
tags:
- "software"
- "software_notifications"
- "software_notifications_email"
- "software_notifications_teams"
- "software_notifications_slack"
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
lastmod: "2026-01-25T00:21:23.886Z"
---
# Notifications
DocStatic uses [GitHub Actions](https://docs.github.com/en/actions) to send workflow notifications. Example review and translate notifications are included in the `.github/workflows/` folder. Some configuration in GitHub is required to enable them. You can also use them as the starting point to develop your own custom notifications.
## Email
The `email-review.yml `and `email-translate.yml` actions are triggered when either the review or translate tags are set on a markdown file in the main branch. To use them, add these [secrets](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/how-tos/write-workflows/choose-what-workflows-do/use-secrets) to your repository:
* `SMTP_SERVER`
* `SMTP_PORT`
* `SMTP_USERNAME`
* `SMTP_PASSWORD`
* `NOTIFY_EMAIL_TO`
* `NOTIFY_EMAIL_FROM`
You can get this information from your email provider. For example:
* [iCloud](https://support.apple.com/en-us/102525) (requires an [app-specific-password)](https://support.apple.com/en-us/102654).
* [Outlook](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/pop-imap-and-smtp-settings-for-outlook-com-d088b986-291d-42b8-9564-9c414e2aa040)
## Slack
The `slack-review.yml `and `slack-translate.yml` actions use the same triggers as the email versions. To use them, add your Slack webhook URL as a secret named `SLACK_WEBHOOK_URL`. For more information, refer to [Sending messages using incoming webhooks](https://docs.slack.dev/messaging/sending-messages-using-incoming-webhooks/) in the Slack documentation.
## Teams
The `teams-review.yml `and `teams-translate.yml` actions work like the Slack versions. Microsoft is deprecating the **Incoming Webhooks** app for Teams from December 2025, but currently there isn't a publicly available GitHub method for sending Adaptive Cards to workflows. The workaround is to use curl:
```yaml
- name: Send Teams test notification
run: |
curl --ssl-no-revoke -X POST \
--location ${{ secrets.MS_TEAMS_HTTP_POST_URL }} \
--header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
--data '{ \
"type": "message", \
"attachments": [{ \
"contentType": "application/vnd.microsoft.card.adaptive", \
"content": { \
"$schema": "http://adaptivecards.io/schemas/adaptive-card.json", \
"type": "AdaptiveCard", \
"version": "1.3", \
"body": [ { \
"type": "TextBlock", \
"text": "This is a test notification from GitHub Actions (Teams).", \
"wrap": true }]}}]}'
```
1. In Teams, go to the channel you want to send messages, click the elipsis (**…**) and select **Workflows**.
2. Click **Manage**.
3. Click **New Flow**.
4. Search templates for webhooks and click **Send webhook alerts to a channel**.
5. (Optional) Edit the **Flow name**.
6. Sign in and click **Next**.
7. Select a **Team** and **Channel** from the lists and click **Create Flow**.
8. Copy the `MS_TEAMS_HTTP_POST_URL` and store it as a secret in GitHub and click **Done**.
<Admonition type="tip" title="Tip">
You can use the Test notifications GitHub action to test your connections.
</Admonition>
segment.target:
---
title: Notifications
lastmod: '2025-10-19T12:47:42.346Z'
description: >-
Envoi de notifications de flux de travail par courrier électronique, Slack ou
Teams.
tags:
- software
- software_notifications
- software_notifications_email
- software_notifications_teams
- software_notifications_slack
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
# Notifications
DocStatic utilise [GitHub Actions](https://docs.github.com/en/actions) pour envoyer des notifications de flux de travail. Des exemples de notifications de révision et de traduction sont inclus dans le dossier `.github/workflows/`. Une configuration dans GitHub est nécessaire pour les activer. Vous pouvez également les utiliser comme point de départ pour développer vos propres notifications personnalisées.
## Email
Les actions `email-review.yml `et `email-translate.yml` sont déclenchées lorsque les balises review ou translate sont définies sur un fichier markdown dans la branche principale. Pour les utiliser, ajoutez ces [secrets](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/how-tos/write-workflows/choose-what-workflows-do/use-secrets) à votre dépôt :
* `SMTP_SERVER`
* `SMTP_PORT`
* `SMTP_USERNAME`
* `SMTP_PASSWORD`
* `NOTIFY_EMAIL_TO`
* `NOTIFY_EMAIL_FROM`
Vous pouvez obtenir cette information auprès de votre fournisseur de messagerie. Par exemple, vous pouvez obtenir cette information auprès de votre fournisseur de messagerie :
* [iCloud](https://support.apple.com/en-us/102525) (nécessite un \[mot de passe spécifique à l'application])([https://support.apple.com/en-us/102654](https://support.apple.com/en-us/102654))).
* [Outlook](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/pop-imap-and-smtp-settings-for-outlook-com-d088b986-291d-42b8-9564-9c414e2aa040)
## Slack
Les actions `slack-review.yml `et `slack-translate.yml` utilisent les mêmes déclencheurs que les versions email. Pour les utiliser, ajoutez l'URL de votre webhook Slack en tant que secret nommé `SLACK_WEBHOOK_URL`. Pour plus d'informations, consultez [Sending messages using incoming webhooks](https://docs.slack.dev/messaging/sending-messages-using-incoming-webhooks/) dans la documentation de Slack.
## Équipes
Les actions `teams-review.yml `et `teams-translate.yml` fonctionnent comme les versions Slack. Microsoft supprime l'application **Incoming Webhooks** pour Teams à partir de décembre 2025, mais il n'y a actuellement pas de méthode GitHub publiquement disponible pour envoyer des cartes adaptatives à des flux de travail. La solution consiste à utiliser curl :
```yaml
- name: Send Teams test notification
run: |
curl --ssl-no-revoke -X POST \
--location ${{ secrets.MS_TEAMS_HTTP_POST_URL }} \
--header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
--data '{ \
"type": "message", \
"attachments": [{ \
"contentType": "application/vnd.microsoft.card.adaptive", \
"content": { \
"$schema": "http://adaptivecards.io/schemas/adaptive-card.json", \
"type": "AdaptiveCard", \
"version": "1.3", \
"body": [ { \
"type": "TextBlock", \
"text": "This is a test notification from GitHub Actions (Teams).", \
"wrap": true }]}}]}'
```
1. Dans Teams, accédez au canal dans lequel vous souhaitez envoyer des messages, cliquez sur l'ellipse (**...**) et sélectionnez **Workflows**.
2. Cliquez sur **Mange**.
3. Cliquez sur **New flow**.
4. Recherchez des modèles pour les webhooks et cliquez sur **Send webhook alerts to a channel**.
5. (Facultatif) Modifiez le **Flow name**.
6. Connectez-vous et cliquez sur **Next**.
7. Sélectionnez une **Team** et un **Channel** dans les listes et cliquez sur **Create Flow**.
8. Copiez le `MS_TEAMS_HTTP_POST_URL` et stockez-le en tant que secret dans GitHub et cliquez sur **Done**.
<Admonition type="tip" title="Conseil">
Vous pouvez utiliser l'action GitHub Test notifications pour tester vos connexions.
</Admonition>

segment.source:
---
title: Style checking
description: Spelling, grammar and style checking in DocStatic.
tags:
- "software"
- "software_grammar-spelling-style"
- "software_grammar-spelling-style_languagetool"
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
lastmod: "2026-01-25T00:21:23.876Z"
---
# Style checking
One of the features most missed by writers working in docs-as-code is a good spelling, grammar and style checker. By default, spell-checking is provided by your web browser or integrated development environment. This may be adequate for simple websites, but if you need something more advanced then you need a dedicated grammar checker.
## LanguageTool
DocStatic is tested with [LanguageTool](https://languagetool.org/), an AI-based grammar checker that supports over 20 languages. It's free to [register](https://languagetool.org/register) for the basic plan. The [premium plan](https://languagetool.org/premium) adds style-guide support for individuals and teams. Tailored [businesses](https://languagetool.org/sales) plans are available. There is also a [discount](https://languagetool.org/premium) for students and non-profits.
## Self hosted
Because LanguageTool is open-source, you have the option of [self-hosting](https://languagetool.org/dev). In this case there are no subscription fees, but you will need a development team to set up your LanguageTool instance, and you'll have to provide your own support.
segment.target:
---
title: Contrôle du style
lastmod: "2025-10-19T16:38:32.517Z"
description: Vérification de l'orthographe, de la grammaire et du style dans DocStatic.
tags:
- "software"
- "software_grammar-spelling-style"
- "software_grammar-spelling-style_languagetool"
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
# Contrôle du style
L'une des fonctionnalités qui manque le plus aux rédacteurs travaillant dans des documents comme code est un bon correcteur d'orthographe, de grammaire et de style. Par défaut, le correcteur orthographique est fourni par votre navigateur web ou votre environnement de développement intégré. Cela peut suffire pour des sites web simples, mais si vous avez besoin de quelque chose de plus avancé, il vous faut un vérificateur de grammaire dédié.
## LanguageTool
DocStatic a été testé avec [LanguageTool](https://languagetool.org/fr/), un correcteur grammatical établi sur l'intelligence artificielle qui prend en charge plus de 20 langues. L'inscription à l'offre originelle est gratuite ([https://languagetool.org/fr/register](https://languagetool.org/fr/register)). Le [plan premium](https://languagetool.org/fr/premium) ajoute la prise en charge des guides de style pour les individus et les équipes. Des plans sur mesure pour les [entreprises](https://languagetool.org/fr/sales) sont disponibles. Il existe également une [réduction](https://languagetool.org/fr/premium) pour les étudiants et les organisations à but non lucratif.
## Auto-hébergé
LanguageTool étant un logiciel libre, vous pouvez de l'[auto-héberger](https://languagetool.org/fr/dev). Dans ce cas, aucuns frais n'existent d'abonnement. Vous aurez besoin d'une équipe de développement pour mettre en place votre instance de LanguageTool, et vous devrez assurer votre propre support.

--- id: swagger-petstore-yaml title: "Swagger Petstore YAML" description: "This is a sample server Petstore server." sidebar_label: Introduction sidebar_position: 0 hide_title: true custom_edit_url: null --- import ApiLogo from "@theme/ApiLogo"; import Heading from "@theme/Heading"; import SchemaTabs from "@theme/SchemaTabs"; import TabItem from "@theme/TabItem"; import Export from "@theme/ApiExplorer/Export"; This is a sample server Petstore server. You can find out more about Swagger at [http://swagger.io](http://swagger.io) or on [irc.freenode.net, #swagger](http://swagger.io/irc/). For this sample, you can use the api key `special-key` to test the authorization filters. ## Introduction This API is documented in **OpenAPI format** and is based on [Petstore sample](http://petstore.swagger.io/) provided by [swagger.io](http://swagger.io) team. It was **extended** to illustrate features of [generator-openapi-repo](https://github.com/Rebilly/generator-openapi-repo) tool and [ReDoc](https://github.com/Redocly/redoc) documentation. In addition to standard OpenAPI syntax we use a few [vendor extensions](https://github.com/Redocly/redoc/blob/master/docs/redoc-vendor-extensions.md). ## OpenAPI Specification This API is documented in **OpenAPI format** and is based on [Petstore sample](http://petstore.swagger.io/) provided by [swagger.io](http://swagger.io) team. It was **extended** to illustrate features of [generator-openapi-repo](https://github.com/Rebilly/generator-openapi-repo) tool and [ReDoc](https://github.com/Redocly/redoc) documentation. In addition to standard OpenAPI syntax we use a few [vendor extensions](https://github.com/Redocly/redoc/blob/master/docs/redoc-vendor-extensions.md). ## Cross-Origin Resource Sharing This API features Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) implemented in compliance with [W3C spec](https://www.w3.org/TR/cors/). And that allows cross-domain communication from the browser. All responses have a wildcard same-origin which makes them completely public and accessible to everyone, including any code on any site. ## Authentication Petstore offers two forms of authentication: - API Key - OAuth2 OAuth2 - an open protocol to allow secure authorization in a simple and standard method from web, mobile and desktop applications.
Get access to data while protecting your account credentials. OAuth2 is also a safer and more secure way to give you access.
Security Scheme Type: oauth2
OAuth Flow (implicit):
Authorization URL: http://petstore.swagger.io/api/oauth/dialog
Scopes:
  • write:pets: modify pets in your account
  • read:pets: read your pets
For this sample, you can use the api key `special-key` to test the authorization filters.
Security Scheme Type: apiKey
Header parameter name: api_key
Security Scheme Type: http
HTTP Authorization Scheme: basic
Security Scheme Type: http
HTTP Authorization Scheme: bearer
Security Scheme Type: apiKey
Header parameter name: X-API-Key
Security Scheme Type: openIdConnect
OpenID Connect URL: https://example.com/.well-known/openid-configuration
Security Scheme Type: oauth2
OAuth Flow (authorizationCode):
Token URL: https://example.com/oauth/token
Authorization URL: https://example.com/oauth/authorize
Scopes:
  • read: Grants read access
  • write: Grants write access
  • admin: Grants access to admin operations

Contact

API Support: [apiteam@swagger.io](mailto:apiteam@swagger.io) URL: [https://github.com/Redocly/redoc](https://github.com/Redocly/redoc)

---
id: scalars
title: Scalars
slug: scalars
sidebar_position: 8
---
## Boolean
The `Boolean` scalar type represents `true` or `false`.
## Float
The `Float` scalar type represents signed double-precision fractional values as specified by [IEEE 754](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_floating_point).
## ID
The `ID` scalar type represents a unique identifier, often used to refetch an object or as key for a cache. The ID type appears in a JSON response as a String; however, it is not intended to be human-readable. When expected as an input type, any string (such as `"4"`) or integer (such as `4`) input value will be accepted as an ID.
## JSON
## Reference
References another document, used as a foreign key
## String
The `String` scalar type represents textual data, represented as UTF-8 character sequences. The String type is most often used by GraphQL to represent free-form human-readable text.

---
title: Blog
lastmod: '2025-10-19T11:14:44.852Z'
description: Blogging with DocStatic.
tags:
- content
- content_blog-articles
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
# Blog
The blog feature enables you to create time-stamped articles.
<Admonition type="info" title="Infor">
Refer to [Blog Plugin API Reference](https://docusaurus.io/docs/api/plugins/@docusaurus/plugin-content-blog) in the Docusaurus documentation for an exhaustive list of options.
</Admonition>
1. From the **Blog Articles** collection in the CMS, click **Add File**.
2. Give it a **Title**.
3. Add any **Authors**. For each author, edit the component and add:
1. Their **Name**.
2. Their **Title**.
3. A **URL**.
4. An **Image URL**.
4. Select the publication **Date**. Post-dated articles will not appear until the site is rebuilt.
5. (Optional) Add any taxonomy **Tags**.
6. Enter the content.
7. Click **Save**.
For more information, refer to [Blog](https://docusaurus.io/docs/blog) in the Docusaurus documentation.

title: Blog

description: Bloguer avec DocStatic.
tags:
- "content"
- "content_blog-articles"
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false

---
# Blog
La fonction blog permet de créer des articles horodatés.
<Admonition type="info" title="Infor">
Reportez-vous à [Blog Plugin API Reference](https://docusaurus.io/docs/api/plugins/@docusaurus/plugin-content-blog) dans la documentation de Docusaurus pour une liste exhaustive des options.
</Admonition>
1. Dans la collection **Blog Articles** du CMS, cliquez sur **Add File**.
2. Donnez-lui un **Title**.
3. Ajoutez des **Authors**. Pour chaque auteur, modifiez le composant et ajoutez :
1. Leur **Name**.
2. Leur **Title**.
3. UNE **URL**.
4. Une **Image URL**.
4. Sélectionnez la **Date** de publication. Les articles postdatés n'apparaîtront pas tant que le site ne sera pas reconstruit.
5. (Facultatif) Ajoutez les **Tags** de la taxonomie.
6. Saisissez le contenu.
7. Cliquez sur **Save**.
Pour plus d'informations, voir [Blog](https://docusaurus.io/fr/docs/blog) dans la documentation du Docusaurus.

segment.source:
---
lastmod: '2025-10-19T11:15:35.102Z'
title: Browser support
description: >-
How to keep a reasonable bundle size while ensuring sufficient browser
support.
tags:
- software
- software_browsers
- software_browsers_safari
- software_browsers_firefox
- software_browsers_edge
- software_browsers_chrome
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
DocStatic let's you define the list of supported browsers through a [browserslist configuration](https://github.com/browserslist/browserslist). Typically, websites should run well on any modern browser.
For more information, refer to [Browser support](https://docusaurus.io/docs/browser-support) in the Docusaurus documentation.
## Editing in the CMS
TinaCMS is fully supported with:
* Chrome
* Edge
* Safari
<Admonition type="danger" title="Warning">
TinaCMS has known issues with Firefox that can range from character styles being ignored to work not being saved. You should use a different browser.
</Admonition>
segment.target:
---
title: Prise en charge des navigateurs
lastmod: '2025-10-19T12:19:20.295Z'
description: >-
Comment conserver une taille de paquet raisonnable tout en garantissant une
prise en charge suffisante du navigateur.
tags:
- software
- software_browsers
- software_browsers_safari
- software_browsers_firefox
- software_browsers_edge
- software_browsers_chrome
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
DocStatic vous permet de définir la liste des navigateurs pris en charge au moyen d'une configuration [liste des navigateurs](https://github.com/browserslist/browserslist)). En règle générale, les sites web devraient correctement fonctionner sur n'importe quel navigateur moderne.
Pour plus d'informations, voir [Navigateurs pris en charge](https://docusaurus.io/fr/docs/browser-support) dans la documentation de Docusaurus.
## Édition dans le CMS
TinaCMS est entièrement compatible avec :
* Chrome
* Edge
* Safari
<Admonition type="danger" title="Avertissement">
TinaCMS a des problèmes connus avec Firefox qui peuvent aller de l'ignorance des styles de caractères à la non sauvegarde du travail. Vous devriez utiliser un autre navigateur.
</Admonition>

segment.source:
---
title: CLI
description: DocStatic command line scripts.
tags:
- "software"
- "software_command-line-interface"
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
lastmod: "2026-01-25T00:20:06.644Z"
---
DocStatic provides a set of scripts to help you generate, serve, and deploy your website.
```json
{
// ...
"scripts": {
"docusaurus": "docusaurus",
"dev": "tinacms dev -c \"docusaurus start\" ",
"start": "docusaurus start",
"generate-files": "node scripts/generate-file-list.js",
"prebuild": "yarn generate-files",
"predev": "yarn generate-files",
"build": "tinacms build && docusaurus build",
"build-local": "tinacms build --local --skip-indexing --skip-cloud-checks && docusaurus build",
"swizzle": "docusaurus swizzle",
"deploy": "docusaurus deploy",
"clear": "docusaurus clear",
"serve": "docusaurus serve",
"write-translations": "docusaurus write-translations",
"write-heading-ids": "docusaurus write-heading-ids",
"gen-api-docs": "docusaurus gen-api-docs",
"clean-api-docs": "docusaurus clean-api-docs",
"gen-graphql": "docusaurus docs:generate:graphql",
"gen-api-docs:version": "docusaurus gen-api-docs:version",
"clean-api-docs:version": "docusaurus clean-api-docs:version",
"lint": "biome check apis/ config/ reuse/ scripts/ src/ static/ tina/",
"lint:fix": "biome check apis/ config/ reuse/ scripts/ src/ static/ tina/ --fix"
}
}
```
## DocStatic CLI commands
To invoke the commands, use yarn. For example, yarn dev.
These commands are described in [CLI](https://docusaurus.io/docs/cli) in the Docusaurus documentation:
* docusaurus
* start
* build
* swizzle
* deploy
* clear
* serve
* write-translations
* write-heading-ids
### Automated commands
These commands are run automatically at build time or when starting the dev server:
* generate-files
* prebuild
* predev
### API commands
* clean-api-docs
* gen-api-docs
* gen-graphql
For more information on the OpenAPI commands, refer to [CLI Usage](https://github.com/PaloAltoNetworks/docusaurus-openapi-docs?tab=readme-ov-file#cli-usage) in the Docusaurus OpenAPI Plugin documentation.
For more information on the GraphQL command, refer to [Usage](https://github.com/Zhouzi/docusaurus-graphql-plugin?tab=readme-ov-file#usage) in the Docusaurus GraphQL Plugin documentation.
### Linting commands
For more information about the linting commands, refer to [CLI](https://biomejs.dev/reference/cli/) in the Biome documentation.
segment.target:

Pour plus d'informations sur la commande GraphQL, voir [Usage](https://github.com/Zhouzi/docusaurus-graphql-plugin?tab=readme-ov-file#usage) dans la documentation du plugin GraphQL de Docusaurus.
### Commandes d'archivage
Pour plus d'informations sur les commandes de classement, voir [CLI](https://biomejs.dev/reference/cli/) dans la documentation de Biome.

---
lastmod: '2026-01-31T11:54:05.550Z'
modifiedBy: aowendev <aowen@translationcommons.org>
title: Configuration
description: Configuring your site's behavior through docusaurus.config.ts and more.
tags:
- configuration
- configuration_docusaurus
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
# Configuration
DocStatic site configuration is managed through the `docusaurus.config.ts` file. For information about editing this file directly, refer to [Configuration](https://docusaurus.io/docs/configuration) in the Docusaurus documentation.
To use the CMS to edit the configuration, navigate to the **Settings** collection. From here, you can configure the site's:
* **Title**.
* **Tagline**.
* **Favicon**.
* **GraphQL Schema URL**.
* Default **Color Mode** (dark or light).
* **Footer** items.
* **Languages**.
* **Logo**.
* **OpenAPI** schemas.
* **Syntax Highlighting**.
* **URL**.
* **Navbar**.
* **Sidebar** settings.
* **Blog** settings.
There is a separate **Theme** collection for changing the color scheme and typography settings.

La configuration du site DocStatic est gérée par le fichier `docusaurus.config.ts`. Pour plus d'informations sur l'édition directe de ce fichier, reportez-vous à [Configuration](https://docusaurus.io/fr/docs/configuration) dans la documentation de Docusaurus.
Pour utiliser le CMS afin de modifier la configuration, naviguez vers la collection [Settings](http://localhost:3000/admin#/collections/edit/settings/index). À partir de là, vous pouvez configurer le logo du site, le titre, l'accroche et le pied de page.

segment.source:
---
title: Creating pages
description: Creating pages in the CMS.
tags:
- "computer-languages"
- "computer-languages_javascript"
- "computer-languages_javascript_react"
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
lastmod: "2025-10-19T16:28:06.197Z"
---
# Creating pages
Pages are distinct from other types of content in that they are intended as one-off, standalone content, such as a showcase, playground or support page. They can contain React components and Markdown. Note that pages don't have sidebars.
<Admonition type="info" title="Info">
Refer to the [Pages Plugin API Reference](http://localhost:3000/docs/api/plugins/plugin-content-pages.mdx) in the Docusaurus documentation for an exhaustive list of options.
</Admonition>
## Add a page
1. From the **Pages** collection in the CMS, click **Add File**.
2. Give it a **Title** and a **Description**.
3. Add your content in the rich text editor.
4. Click **Save**.
## Add React components to a page
DocStatic's React components are available globally. But if you're only using a component on one page it doesn't make sense to do this. Instead, you can import the component directly into the page. However, to ensure you can edit the page in the CMS, you need to wrap the import directive in a [Passthrough](/docs/guides/markdown-features/react#passthrough-component) component. The example page on the DocStatic site imports the ColorGenerator component like this:
```markdown
<Passthrough type="jsx" string="import ColorGenerator from '@site/src/components/ColorGenerator';" summary="Import Statement" />
<Passthrough type="jsx" string="<ColorGenerator />" summary="JSX Component" />
```
For more information, refer to [Creating Pages](https://docusaurus.io/docs/creating-pages) in the Docusaurus documentation.
segment.target:
---
title: Création de pages
description: Création de pages dans le CMS.
tags:
- "computer-languages"
- "computer-languages_javascript"
- "computer-languages_javascript_react"
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
lastmod: "2025-10-19T17:02:26.190Z"
---
# Création de pages
Les pages se distinguent des autres types de contenu dans la mesure où elles sont destinées à un contenu unique et autonome, tel qu'une page de présentation, un terrain de jeu ou une page d'assistance. Elles peuvent contenir des composants React et du Markdown. Notez que les pages n'ont pas de barres latérales.
<Admonition type="info" title="Info">
Reportez-vous à la [Référence API du plugin Pages](http://localhost:3000/docs/api/plugins/plugin-content-pages.mdx) dans la documentation de Docusaurus pour une liste exhaustive d'options.
</Admonition>
## Ajouter une page
1. Dans la collection **Pages** du CMS, cliquez sur **Add File**.
2. Donnez-lui un **Title** et une **Description**.
3. Ajoutez votre contenu dans l'éditeur de texte riche.
4. Cliquez sur **Enregistrer**.
## Ajouter des composants React à une page
Les composants React de DocStatic sont disponibles globalement. Mais si vous n'utilisez un composant que sur une seule page, cela n'a pas de sens. Au lieu de cela, vous pouvez importer le composant directement dans la page. Toutefois, pour pouvoir modifier la page dans le CMS, vous devez intégrer la directive d'importation dans un composant [Passthrough](/docs/guides/markdown-features/react#passthrough-component). La page d'exemple sur le site DocStatic importe le composant ColorGenerator de la manière suivante :
```markdown
<Passthrough type="jsx" string="import ColorGenerator from '@site/src/components/ColorGenerator' ;" summary="Import Statement" />
<Passthrough type="jsx" string="<ColorGenerator />" summary="JSX Component" />
```
Pour plus d'informations, voir [Création des pages](https://docusaurus.io/fr/docs/creating-pages) dans la documentation de Docusaurus.

segment.source:
---
lastmod: '2026-01-25T13:32:07.634Z'
title: Dashboards
description: Viewing dashboards in TinaCMS
tags:
- content-management-systems
- content-management-systems_tinacms
- content-management-systems_media-management
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
modifiedBy: aowendev <aowen@translationcommons.org>
---
DocStatic adds dashboard functionality to TinaCMS. Tina generates a GraphQL API using the filesystem in the Git repository as the database. Dashboards query the API (locally or in the cloud) and present actionable reports directly in the CMS. Dashboard functionality is currently considered beta. The functionality is fully tested, but the user interface is provisional and requires refinement. Dashboards update when the page is updated. If another user has made changes since you viewed a dashboard, you can click **Refresh** to update the dashboard.
<Admonition type="note" title="Note">
Depending on the amount of content in the system, some dashboards may take some time to load. These dashboards will typically update slightly faster when running locally.
</Admonition>
## Viewing the dashboards
From the CMS, navigate to the Dashboards collection. At the top of the page is a status bar that shows the GraphQL connection. It indicates if you are connected to the cloud or localhost. If the localhost is available, it will always connect to the localhost. To use the cloud, ensure the local dev server is stopped. The status bar also displays the environment and checks all settings are valid.
## Viewing workflow status
The Content Overview dashboard show the total number of topics in the /docs path and the topics in each workflow status:
* Draft
* Review
* Translate
* Approved
* Published
* Unlisted
Click the status link to display all topics in that status.
Click Edit to open the topic for editing.
Click the Close icon to close the list of topics.
### Viewing recent activity
The Recent Activity section shows recently changed topics. You can filter the time range (All time, Last week or Last month) and set the number of results from 5 to 50.
## Viewing translation status
The Translations dashboard shows the status of each topic for the language selected from the list:
* Up to date: The last modified date of the translation is later than the source.
* Outdated: The last modified date of the source is later than the translation.
* Missing: There is a source file with no equivalent translation file.
## Viewing media reuse
The Media Library dashboard shows where content in the /static/img path is used. It shows the total number of files and images, file size, image paths and image sizes.
You can filter by:
* All content.
* Images only.
* Recent (7 days).
* Used.
* Unused.
For used content, click Used in n docs to display the topics where the content is used. You can then click Edit to edit those topics.
## Checking broken links
The Broken Links dashboard validates all the hyperlinks in the topics. The report includes number for:
* Total links.
* Valid links where a connection could be established.
* Broken links where no connection could be established.
* Warning links where the connecton was rejected but the link could still be valid.
You can safely ignore warnings about http\://localhost if you are describing software running locally. But document links should be relative.
Warnings are typically the results of aggressive CORS/CORP policies that do not respect no-cors settings. You must manually validate these sites by clicking the hyperlink.
The dashboard lists files with problem links. You can open them by clicking Edit in either list.
The dashboard also provides a summary with the date when the report was run.

segment.source:
---
title: Create a doc
description: Create a Markdown document.
tags:
- "content"
- "content_topics"
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
lastmod: "2026-01-25T00:21:23.851Z"
---
# Create a doc
In DocStatic, you write your content as Markdown in files called “Topics”. Typically, you will create each topic yourself, although certain types of docs may have autogenerated topics.
<Admonition type="note" title="Note">
GraphQL and OpenAPI docs are autogenerated from a server or schema.
</Admonition>
To create a topic:
1. From the **Topics** collection, click **Add File**.
2. Give the topic a **Title**.
3. (Optional) If you want to use the topic in [context-sensitive help](https://docstatic.com/docs/context-help), give it a **Slug**. This is a fixed path from `/docs/`.
4. Give the topic a **Description**. This is displayed in the Doc Card List.
5. (Optional) Add any required [taxonomy](taxonomies) **Tags**.
6. (Optional) Set any **Conditions**.
7. Make sure the Workflow status is set to **Draft**.
8. Enter your content.
9. Click **Save**.
## Doc front matter
At the start of every topic is a section of YAML contained between two sets of three hyphens (---). DocStatic uses this for things such as:
* Conditional Text
* Taxonomies (doc tags)
* Workflows
For more information, refer to [Create a doc](https://docusaurus.io/docs/create-doc) in the Docusaurus documentation.
segment.target:
---
title: Créer un document
lastmod: '2025-10-19T12:54:39.453Z'
description: Créer un document Markdown.
tags:
- content
- content_topics
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
# Créer un document
Dans DocStatic, vous écrivez votre contenu en Markdown dans des fichiers appelés "Topics". En règle générale, vous créez vous-même chaque sujet, bien que certains types de documents puissent avoir des sujets autogénérés.
<Admonition type="note" title="Note">
Les documents GraphQL et OpenAPI sont autogénérés à partir d'un serveur ou d'un schéma.
</Admonition>
Pour créer un sujet :
1. Dans la collection **Topics**, cliquez sur **Add File**.
2. Donnez un **Title** à la rubrique.
3. (Facultatif) Si vous souhaitez utiliser la rubrique dans [l'aide contextuelle](https://docstatic.com/docs/context-help), offrez-lui un **Slug**. Il s'agit d'un chemin fixe à partir de `/docs/`.
4. Offrez à la rubrique une **Description**. Celle-ci est affichée dans la liste des cartes de documents.
5. (Facultatif) Ajoutez les **Tags** de la [taxonomie](taxonomies).
6. (Facultatif) Définir les **Conditions**.
7. Assurez-vous que le statut du flux de travail est défini sur **Draft**.
8. Saisissez votre contenu.
9. Cliquez sur **Save**.
## Document recto
Au début de chaque sujet se trouve une section de YAML contenue entre deux séries de trois traits d'union (---). DocStatic l'utilise pour des choses telles que :
* Texte conditionnel
* Taxonomies (étiquettes de documents)
* les flux de travail
Pour plus d'informations, voir [Créer un doc](https://docusaurus.io/fr/docs/create-doc) dans la documentation de Docusaurus.

segment.source:
---
title: Taxonomies
lastmod: '2025-10-19T11:19:11.485Z'
description: Creating and applying an information architecture in DocStatic.
tags:
- metadata
- metadata_taxonomies
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
# Taxonomies
The more information you have, the harder it is to find things. Markdown enables you to tag content, but without any checking for consistency. DocStatic enables you to apply an [information architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_architecture) to your content with taxonomies.
## Designing an information architecture
It's beyond the scope of this document to cover information architecture in great depth, but here are some suggestions:
* Limit your hierarchy to three levels. This maps well to traditional [indexing](/docs/tags).
* Normalize your terms. Prefer plurals over singulars or verbs. Prefer single words over phrases.
* Spell out acronyms and abbreviations.
* Try to limit the top-level to ten categories.
* Try to limit the mid-level to seven categories.
* Use as many leaf-level categories as required.
## Applying a hierarchy to flat tag systems
Ideally, you should apply the information architecture to all your information platforms (bug-tracking systems, wikis and so on). This means that tags have to meet the most restrictive criteria:
* Tags must contain their own parent categories, separated by an underscore ( \_ ).
* Lowercase letters only. No numerals, spaces (use a hyphen instead) or special characters.
To prevent the tags becoming unreasonably long, nesting is limited to a maximum depth of three levels. In some cases, this requires flattening the structure. For example, while `regions_europe_uk_scotland` is logical, it has four levels and so must be structured as `regions_uk_scotland`.
## Managing taxonomy tags
When tagging content in the CMS, you are limited to the set of tags that you define.
1. Select Taxonomies from the collections and Add a taxonomy.
2. Add any mid-level child tags. These should include the parent tag (parent\_child).
3. Add any leaf-level child tags. These should include the parent tag (top\_mid\_leaf).
<Admonition type="note" title="Note">
You don't have to include the parent and an underscore in a child tag, but if you leave them out then you'll be presented with a flat list of tags when you add a tag to a topic.
</Admonition>
## Tagging content
In the CMS when editing a topic you can either use Search Mode to search for a term or select it from the Tree View. When you add a tag, all parent tags are added automatically. However, only one instance of each tag is added.
<Admonition type="tip" title="Tip">
Avoid tagging content outside the CMS. This will keep your tags consistent and make searching for content easier.
</Admonition>
segment.target:
---
title: Taxonomies
lastmod: '2025-10-19T12:58:33.186Z'
description: Création et application d'une architecture de l'information dans DocStatic.
tags:
- metadata
- metadata_taxonomies
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
# Taxonomies
Plus il y a d'informations, plus il est difficile de les retrouver. Markdown vous permet d'étiqueter le contenu, mais sans aucun contrôle de cohérence. DocStatic vous permet d'appliquer une [architecture de l'information](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Architecture_de_l%27information) à votre contenu à l'aide de taxonomies.
## Concevoir une architecture de l'information
L'architecture de l'information n'entre pas dans le cadre de ce document, mais voici quelques suggestions :
* Limitez votre hiérarchie à trois niveaux. Cela correspond bien à l'indexation traditionnelle (/docs/tags).
* Normalisez vos termes. Préférez les pluriels aux singuliers ou aux verbes. Préférez les mots simples aux phrases.
* Écrivez en toutes lettres les acronymes et les abréviations.
* Essayez de limiter le niveau supérieur à dix catégories.
* Essayez de limiter le niveau intermédiaire à sept catégories.
* Utiliser autant de catégories que nécessaire au niveau des feuilles.
## Application d'une hiérarchie à des systèmes d'étiquetage plats
Idéalement, vous devriez appliquer l'architecture de l'information à toutes vos plateformes d'information (systèmes de suivi des bogues, wikis, etc.). Cela signifie que les balises doivent répondre aux critères les plus restrictifs :
* Les balises doivent contenir leurs propres catégories parentes, séparées par un trait de soulignement ( \_ ).
* Lettres minuscules uniquement. Pas de chiffres, d'espaces (utilisez plutôt un trait d'union) ou de caractères spéciaux.
Pour éviter que les balises ne deviennent trop longues, l'imbrication est limitée à une profondeur maximale de trois niveaux. Dans certains cas, vous devez aplatir la structure. Par exemple, bien que `regions_europe_uk_scotland` soit logique, il a quatre niveaux et doit donc être structuré comme `regions_uk_scotland`.
## Gestion des balises de taxonomie
Lorsque vous étiquetez du contenu dans le CMS, vous êtes restreint à l'ensemble des étiquettes que vous définissez.
1. Sélectionnez Taxonomies dans les collections et Ajouter une taxonomie.
2. Ajoutez toutes les balises enfant de niveau intermédiaire. Celles-ci doivent inclure la balise parente (`parent_child`).
3. Ajoutez toutes les balises enfant de niveau feuille. Elles doivent inclure la balise parente (`top_mid_leaf`).
<Admonition type="note" title="Note">
Il n'est pas nécessaire d'inclure le parent et un trait de soulignement dans une balise enfant, mais si vous ne le faites pas, vous obtiendrez une liste plate de balises lorsque vous ajouterez une balise à un thème.
</Admonition>
## Baliser le contenu
Dans le CMS, lorsque vous modifiez une rubrique, vous pouvez soit utiliser le mode recherche pour rechercher un terme, soit le sélectionner dans l'arborescence. Lorsque vous ajoutez une balise, toutes les balises parentes sont automatiquement ajoutées. Cependant, une seule instance de chaque balise est ajoutée.
<Admonition type="tip" title="Conseil">
Évitez de baliser le contenu en dehors du CMS. Ainsi, vos balises resteront cohérentes et la recherche de contenu sera plus facile.
</Admonition>

segment.source:
---
title: Admonitions
description: Handling admonitions/callouts in DocStatic.
tags:
- "elements"
- "elements_admonitions"
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
lastmod: "2026-01-25T00:21:23.844Z"
---
# Admonitions
The **Admonitions** component enables you to add styled admonitions.
1. Select **Admonition** from the **Embed** list.
2. Edit the component and select a **Type** (**Note**, **Tip**, **Info**, **Caution** or **Warning**).
3. Give it a **Title**.
4. Enter the **Content**.
#### Examples:
<Admonition type="note" title="Note">
Use note admonitions for supplementary information.
</Admonition>
<Admonition type="tip" title="Tip">
Use tip admonitions to provide advice that it's safe to ignore.
</Admonition>
<Admonition type="info" title="Info">
Use info admonitions for information that's sufficiently important that it needs to stand apart from the rest of the text.
</Admonition>
<Admonition type="caution" title="Caution">
Use caution admonitions when something may prevent an intended action from being completed.
</Admonition>
<Admonition type="danger" title="Warning">
Use warning admonitions when there is a risk of injury, security breach or data loss.
</Admonition>
segment.target:
---
title: Admonitions
lastmod: '2025-10-19T13:05:03.250Z'
description: Gestion des avertissements/rappels dans DocStatic.
tags:
- elements
- elements_admonitions
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
# Admonitions
Le composant **Admonitions** vous permet d'ajouter des avertissements stylisés.
1. Sélectionnez **Admonition** dans la liste **Embed**.
2. Modifiez le composant et sélectionnez un **Type** (**Note**, **Conseil**, **Info**, **Caution** ou **Warning**).
3. Donnez-lui un **Title**.
4. Saisissez le **Content**.
#### Exemples :
<Admonition type="note" title="Note">
Utilisez les admonitions de note pour obtenir des informations supplémentaires.
</Admonition>
<Admonition type="tip" title="Conseil">
Utilisez les avertissements de type "tip" pour fournir des conseils qu'il est prudent d'ignorer.
</Admonition>
<Admonition type="info" title="Info">
Utilisez les avertissements de type "info" pour les informations suffisamment importantes pour se démarquer du reste du texte.
</Admonition>
<Admonition type="caution" title="Prudence">
Utilisez les avertissements de prudence lorsque quelque chose risque d'empêcher la réalisation d'une action prévue.
</Admonition>
<Admonition type="danger" title="Avertissement">
Utilisez des avertissements lorsqu'il existe un risque de blessure, de violation de la sécurité ou de perte de données.
</Admonition>

segment.source:
---
title: Assets
description: Handling assets in DocStatic.
tags:
- "content"
- "content_images"
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
lastmod: "2026-01-25T00:21:23.820Z"
---
# Assets
Sometimes you want to link to assets (for example, docx files, images and so on) directly from topics. DocStatic manages this through the static/ folder.
Any content placed in the folder will be available from the root of the published site. For example:
```
# Your doc
/website/docs/myFeature.mdx
# Some assets you want to use
/website/assets/docstatic-asset-example.docx
/website/img/docstastic-asset-example-banner.png
```
## Images
DocStatic provides two ways to add images to topics. For inline images you can click the **Image** icon to place an image in a topic. This works best for icons (![](/img/docs/example.svg)) and small images. Icons should be stored as pre-scaled SVG files. These will be inverted and have their color space rotated by 180° in dark mode.
<Admonition type="tip" title="Tip">
You can use [Librsvg](https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/LibRsvg) to scale SVGs. For example, `rsvg-convert example.svg -h 12 -f svg -o example.svg` sets a height of 12 points.
</Admonition>
For larger images, it's better to use the Figure component.
1. Select **Figure** from the **Embed** list.
2. Edit the component.
3. Click the **Image** area to open the **Media Manager**.
4. Upload or select an image.
5. Give it a **Caption**.
#### Example
<Figure img="/img/docStaticDemo.jpg" caption="Example Figure" size="" />
The figure resizes based on the view window. Clicking it will open it at maximum size in a light box.
For more information about the Media Manager, refer to [Media Overview](https://tina.io/docs/reference/media/overview) in the TinaCMS documentation.
## Files
In the same way you can link to existing assets by using the path from the static/ folder in the URL. For example:
```
./assets/docstatic-asset-example.docx
```
For more information, refer to [Static assets](https://docusaurus.io/docs/markdown-features/assets) in the Docusaurus documentation.
segment.target:
---
title: Ressources
lastmod: '2025-10-19T13:04:06.226Z'
description: Gestion des actifs dans DocStatic.
tags:
- content
- content_images
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
# Ressources
Parfois, vous souhaitiez créer des liens vers des ressources (par exemple, des fichiers docx, des images, etc.) directement à partir des rubriques. DocStatic dirige cela à travers le dossier static/.
Tout contenu placé dans ce dossier sera disponible à la racine du site publié. Par exemple, dans le cas de DocStatic, il s'agit d'un dossier statique :
```
# Votre document
/website/docs/myFeature.mdx
# Quelques actifs que vous voulez utiliser
/website/assets/docstatic-asset-example.docx
/website/img/docstastic-asset-example-banner.png
```
## Images
DocStatic propose deux façons d'ajouter des images aux rubriques. Pour les images en ligne, vous pouvez cliquer sur l'icône Image pour placer une image dans une rubrique. Cette méthode fonctionne mieux pour les icônes et les petites images. Pour les images plus grandes, il est préférable d'utiliser le composant Figure.
1. Sélectionnez **Figure** dans la liste **Embed**.
2. Modifiez le composant.
3. Cliquez sur la zone **Image** pour ouvrir le **Media Manager**.
4. Téléchargez ou sélectionnez une image.
5. Donnez-lui une **Caption**.
#### Exemple :
<Figure img="/img/docStaticDemo.jpg" caption="Exemple de figure" size="" />
La figure est redimensionnée en fonction de la fenêtre d'affichage. En cliquant dessus, vous l'ouvrirez à sa taille maximale dans une boîte lumineuse.
Pour plus d'informations sur le gestionnaire de médias, reportez-vous à [Media Overview](https://tina.io/docs/reference/media/overview) dans la documentation de TinaCMS.
## Fichiers
De la même manière, vous pouvez créer un lien vers des ressources existantes avec le chemin du dossier static/ dans l'URL. Par exemple, vous pouvez créer un lien vers un fichier existant avec le chemin du dossier `static/` dans l'URL :
```
./assets/docstatic-asset-example.docx
```
Pour plus d'informations, voir [Ressources](https://docusaurus.io/fr/docs/markdown-features/assets) dans la documentation de Docusaurus.

segment.source:
---
title: Code blocks and snippets
description: Handling code blocks in DocStatic.
tags:
- "elements"
- "elements_code-blocks"
- "reuse"
- "reuse_snippets"
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
lastmod: "2026-01-25T00:21:23.803Z"
---
# Code blocks and snippets
DocStatic provides two ways to include code in your documentation. Both support syntax highlighting.
## Code blocks
1. Click the **Code Block** icon in the rich text editor.
2. Click the language list and select or search for a language.
3. Enter your code in the box.
#### Example:
```plaintext
This is some plain text.
```
## Code snippets
1. Select **Code Snippet** from the **Embed** list.
2. Give it a **Title**.
3. Select a **Language**.
4. Choose a file from the list. The list is populated with all the files in the `reuse/code/` folder every time you run the dev server or do a build.
#### Example:
<CodeSnippet title="Example Title" language="xml" filepath="example.xml" />
The advantage of using code snippets is that there is a physical file that can be unit tested.
segment.target:

title: Blocs de code et extraits
lastmod: '2025-10-19T13:10:09.774Z'
description: Gestion des blocs de code dans DocStatic.
tags:
- elements
- elements_code-blocks
- reuse

draft: false

published: true
unlisted: false
---
# Blocs de code et extraits
DocStatic propose deux façons d'inclure du code dans votre documentation. Toutes deux prennent en charge la mise en évidence de la syntaxe.
## Blocs de code
1. Cliquez sur l'icône **Code Block** dans l'éditeur de texte riche.
2. Cliquez sur la liste des langues et sélectionnez ou recherchez une langue.
3. Saisissez votre code dans la boîte.
#### Exemple :
```plaintext
Voici du texte en clair.
```
## Extraits de code
1. Sélectionnez **Code Snippet** dans la liste **Embed**.
2. Donnez-lui un **Title**.
3. Sélectionnez une **Language**.
4. Choisissez un fichier dans la liste. La liste est remplie avec tous les fichiers du dossier `reuse/code/` chaque fois que vous lancez le serveur de développement ou que vous faites une compilation.
#### Exemple :
<CodeSnippet title="Titre de l'exemple" language="xml" filepath="example.xml" />
L'avantage d'utiliser des extraits de code est qu'il existe un fichier physique qui peut être testé de manière unitaire.

segment.source:
---
lastmod: '2026-02-18T23:00:48.814Z'
modifiedBy: aowendev <aowen@translationcommons.org>
title: Conditional text
conditions:
- production
description: Filtering content with conditional text settings.
tags:
- metadata
- metadata_conditions
- reuse
- reuse_conditional-text
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
# Conditional text
The **Conditional Text** component enables you to wrap conetnt in a set of conditions that determine when it should be displayed:
* Conditions can be any combination of languages or user-defined conditions.
* The content can be displayed or hidden if one or more conditions are met (OR) or only if all conditions are met (AND).
You can also specify fallback text to display if no conditions are met.
## Create categories and conditions
1. In the CMS, click the **Conditions** collection.
2. Click the **Add** icon to add a new **Category**
3. Give it a **Name** and **Description**.
4. For each **Condition** you want to add:
1. Click the **Add** icon.
2. Name the **Condition** and give it a **Description**.
3. Toggle the **Active** status of the condition as required.
## Add conditions to a topic
Conditions are set at the topic level. The language is determined by the page language. Other conditions are defined as an array in the metadata at the start of the topic.
1. Create or edit a topic.
2. In the **Conditions** area, expand the **Categories** and select the box of any **Conditions** you want to apply to the topic.
## Add conditional text
1. Select **Conditional Text** from the **Embed** list.
2. Edit the component.
3. Enter the **Content**.
4. Set the **Action** (show or hide).
5. Add any **Required Conditions**.
6. Add any **Required Languages**.
7. Set the **Condition Logic**.
8. Set the **Language Logic**.
9. Select if both conditions and languages are required.
10. (Optional) Enter the **Fallback Text**.
### Example
<ConditionalText action="show" conditions={["production"]} languages={[]} logic="any" languageLogic="any" requireBothConditions={false} fallback="">The `production` condition is set on this page.</ConditionalText>
segment.target:
---
title: Texte conditionnel
lastmod: '2025-10-19T13:59:00.213Z'
description: Filtrer le contenu avec des paramètres de texte conditionnels.
tags:
- metadata
- metadata_conditions
- reuse
- reuse_conditional-text
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
# Texte conditionnel
Le composant **Conditions** vous permet d'envelopper du texte dans un ensemble de conditions qui déterminent quand il doit être affiché.
Les conditions peuvent être n'importe quelle combinaison de langues ou de conditions définies par l'utilisateur.
Le texte peut être affiché si une ou plusieurs conditions sont remplies (OR) ou seulement si toutes les conditions sont remplies (AND).
Vous pouvez également spécifier un texte de remplacement à afficher si aucune condition n'est remplie.
## Créer des catégories et des conditions
1. Dans le CMS, cliquez sur la collection **Conditions**.
2. Cliquez sur l'icône **Add** pour ajouter une nouvelle **Category**
3. Donnez-lui un **Name** et une **Description**.
4. Pour chaque **Condition** que vous souhaitez ajouter :
1. Cliquez sur l'icône **Add**.
2. Nommez la **Condition** et donnez-lui une **Description**.
3. Faites basculer le statut **Active** de la condition si nécessaire.
## Ajouter des conditions à une rubrique
Les conditions sont définies au niveau de la rubrique. La langue est déterminée par la langue de la page. Les autres conditions sont définies sous forme de tableau dans les métadonnées au début du sujet.
1. Créez ou modifiez une rubrique.
2. Dans la zone **Conditions**, développez les **Categories** et cochez la case des **Conditions** que vous souhaitez appliquer au sujet.
## Ajouter un texte conditionnel
1. Sélectionnez **Conditional Text** dans la liste **Embed**.
2. Modifiez le composant.
3. Saisissez le **Text Content**.
4. Ajoutez les **Required Conditions**.
5. Ajoutez les **Required Languages**.
6. Définissez la **Condition Logic**.
7. Définissez la **Language Logic**.
8. Sélectionnez si les deux conditions et les deux langues sont requises.
9. (Facultatif) Saisissez le **Fallback Text**.

segment.source:
---
title: Context-sensitive help
slug: "/context-help"
description: Using anchor tags to provide conditional sensitive help.
tags:
- "elements"
- "elements_context-sensitive-help"
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
lastmod: "2026-01-25T00:21:23.811Z"
---
# Context-sensitive help
> "Context-sensitive help is a kind of [online help](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_help) that is obtained from a specific point in the state of the software, providing help for the situation that is associated with that state. Context-sensitive help, as opposed to general online help or online manuals, does not need to be accessible for reading as a whole. Each topic is supposed to describe extensively one state, situation, or feature of the software."—[Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Context-sensitive_help)
Typically, context-sensitive help is implemented by having a help icon that users can click that will take them to the appropriate part of the documentation for the part of the software they are using. This involves creating a map of context URLs.
The static site generator automatically generates links to headings. However, if you change the heading, the link will change. For this reason, DocStatic provides the Context Help element. It enables you to add an anchor tag anywhere within a topic. Providing that a slug is defined for the topic in the metadata, the link will not break.
1. Select **Context Help** from the Embed list.
2. Enter a unique ID.
The link will be in the form: `<URL>/docs/<slug>#<id>`.
#### Examlpe
[https://docstatic.com/docs/context-help#help-example](/docs/context-help#help-example)
<a id="help-example" />
## Developers
For an example of how to include context help links in your code, examine the HelpButton React component in the source code for this site. Because DocStatic doesn't have direct access to the CMS code, it implements the button by applying it as a UI element on an unused field in a CMS collection. The HelpButton component attaches the button to the nav element on the page and links it to the URL passed in the template:
```javascript
const ExampleCollection = {
name: "example",
label: "Example",
path: "docs/example",
format: "mdx",
fields: [
{
type: "boolean",
name: "help",
label: "Help",
required: false,
ui: {
component: (props) => <HelpButton url="https://example.com/" {...props} />,
},
},
```
segment.target:
---
title: Aide contextuelle
lastmod: '2025-10-19T13:07:51.297Z'
description: >-
Utilisation de balises d'ancrage pour fournir une aide conditionnelle
sensible.
slug: /context-help
tags:
- elements
- elements_context-sensitive-help
draft: false
review: false
translate: false
approved: false
published: true
unlisted: false
---
# Aide contextuelle
> "L'aide contextuelle est un type d'[aide en ligne](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aide_en_ligne) qui est obtenu à partir d'un point spécifique de l'état du logiciel, fournissant de l'aide pour la situation qui est associée à cet état. L'aide contextuelle, contrairement à l'aide en ligne générale ou aux manuels en ligne, n'a pas besoin d'être accessible à la lecture dans son ensemble. Chaque rubrique est censée décrire de manière exhaustive un état, une situation ou une fonctionnalité du logiciel." - [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Context-sensitive_help)
En règle générale, l'aide contextuelle est mise en œuvre au moyen d'une icône d'aide sur laquelle l'utilisateur peut cliquer et qui l'amène à la partie de la documentation correspondant à la partie du logiciel qu'il utilise. Cela implique la création d'une carte des URL contextuelles.
Le générateur de site statique génère automatiquement des liens vers les titres. Cependant, si vous modifiez le titre, le lien changera. C'est pourquoi DocStatic fournit l'élément Aide contextuelle. Il vous permet d'ajouter une balise d'ancrage n'importe où dans un sujet. À condition qu'une balise soit définie pour le sujet dans les métadonnées, le lien ne sera pas rompu.
1. Sélectionnez **Context Helpe** dans la liste **Embed**.
2. Saisissez un identifiant unique.
Le lien se présentera sous la forme suivante : `<URL>/docs/<slug>#<id>` : `<URL>/docs/<slug>#<id>`.
#### Exemple
[https://docstatic.com/docs/fr/context-help#help-example](/docs/fr/context-help#help-example)
<a id="help-example" />
## Développeurs
Pour un exemple de la façon d'inclure des liens d'aide contextuelle dans votre code, examinez le composant React HelpButton dans le code source de ce site. DocStatic n'ayant pas d'accès direct au code du CMS, il implémente le bouton en l'appliquant en tant qu'élément d'interface utilisateur sur un champ inutilisé dans une collection du CMS. Le composant HelpButton attache le bouton à l'élément nav de la page et le lie à l'URL passée dans le modèle :
```javascript
const ExampleCollection = {
name: "example",
label: "Example",
path: "docs/example",
format: "mdx",
fields: [
{
type: "boolean",
name: "help",
label: "Help",
required: false,
ui: {
component: (props) => <HelpButton url="https://example.com/" {...props} />,
},
},
```
